data.title: GraphicsDevice does not call glGetError after requesting the number of draw buffers
data.body:
GraphicsDevice (in SetupGL, at around line 417) fetches some integers using glGetInteger, and calls glGetError correctly after most of them. However, it doesn't call it after this line:

``` csharp
            GL.GetInteger(GetPName.MaxDrawBuffers, out maxDrawBuffers);
```

(I'm doing some dev on an implementation that doesn't support draw buffers, so this is generating an error that isn't actually detected by GraphicsDevice, and gets caught in some other unrelated part of MG that checks the error state later)

data.title: Fixes Song bug.
data.body:
I found strange song bug on WinDx platform and makes a solution. This bug is in the call of method MediaPlayer.Play. It play song once but at another time(closing and another runs of a game) - it emit exception at MediaFactory.GetService in internal PlaySong method - "Not supported Interface". It emits exception not always but during some period of time - after this period it play song once more and again run that time period. Probably this is Sharpdx internal problem or monogame does not disposes com-interfaces correctly...  In debug mode when you set debugging point on this method it load interfaces correctly but if not - this exception emits. And If you call it once again after this exception in try/catch- it loads correctly. 

Also im added Obsolete atribute to Keyboard.GetState(PlayerIndex) - this method is dublicate GetState and must be deleted in the future versions - I marked it obsolete for make attention to developers.

data.title: Weird multiple render target behavior in DirectX.
data.body:
Multiple render targets are not working correctly under DirectX.  I've attached a sample program at https://gist.github.com/optimality/6025190.

This program renders a full-screen quad twice with two different shaders.  The first shader renders a red gradient and a blue gradient to two different render targets.  The second shader takes two input textures and blends them.

The expected behavior is that there will be a purple gradient on the screen (bluer on the side, redder on the bottom, black in the top left).  The actual behavior is that I get a black screen.

For diagnosis, I added some other modes:
- Holding down the "A" key will replace the gradients with solid red and blue textures.  They are correctly merged on the screen (it turns purple).
- Holding down the "B" key is supposed to draw the first render target to the screen in the top left.  Nothing happens.
- Here's the really weird part.  Holding down the "C" key draws the second texture to the screen in the top left.  And the background also changes to display the red gradient (but doesn't merge in the blue gradient).  Holding down "B" and "C" draws both textures to the top left, but doesn't merge them in the background (which continues to only draw one texture).

I can't for the life of me figure out what could be causing this weird behavior.

data.title: Potential Android and windowsGL video fix
A Better Content Pipeline
data.body:
I would like to see if we can come up with improvements to the XNA content pipeline to eventually include in the new MonoGame content pipeline.

There are a few issues that I commonly have:
- Artists don't have Visual Studio... cannot work with .contentproj files.
- Conflicts with .contentproj files are common with all content in one file.
- Hard to build content with different settings or different source art for different platforms.
- How .contentproj is setup is complex to understand.
- Content building is single threaded and slow.

Some things I think we can do to improve things over XNA:
- Write a small stand alone content GUI tool for use by artists.
- Ditch .contentproj and MSBuild in favor of a simpler content format that an artist has a chance to read understand.
- Instead of one .contentproj with all content build instructions in it... support multiple smaller content command files.
- Add support for multithreaded content building within the content pipeline runner.
- Some form of conditionals within content command files.

Any other ideas as to how best we can evolve the content pipeline beyond XNA 4.0?

data.title: MGFX Reflection Fix
data.body:
This is a cleaned up version of PR #1846 by @nightst4r which addresses issue #1845.

It fixes cases where we were marshaling within a union which can cause type reflection to fail.  This then causes our content processors to fail to be loaded by XNA on some systems.  Removing the marshaling within unions fixes this.

Note this does not affect effect processing at all really.  The unions in question are not being used by MGFX.

data.title: Solving the OpenTK mess
data.body:
While experimenting with multisampled rendertargets on Android and iOS for our game Infinite Flight, I found that a good option to solve the OpenTK mess (implementation differences on each platform, extension support always behind ... etc) would be to simply create the bindings ourselves where we need them instead of having to rely on yet another external dependency.
OpenGL bindings are usually only needed in one place which would make things very simple to debug and maintain. Below is an example of how it could look for the RenderTarget2D class.

```
public class RenderTarget2D : Texture2D, IRenderTarget
{
#if GLES
    [DllImport(Platform.LibGLES, EntryPoint = "glRenderbufferStorageMultisampleIMG")]
    private extern static void GLRenderbufferStorageMultisampleIMG(All target, int samples, All internalformat, int width, int height);
    [DllImport(Platform.LibGLES, EntryPoint = "glRenderbufferStorageMultisampleEXT")]
    private extern static void GLRenderbufferStorageMultisampleEXT(All target, int samples, All internalformat, int width, int height);
```

I would even recommend to declare the necessary OpenGL enums in place to make it easy for more contributors to understand the code.

MonoGame/XNA is already a wrapper ... it would probably be best for it to directly access the native API instead of relying on another wrapper (OpenTK or whatever comes next).

The great thing about this is that it is a change that could happen gradually with small and focused pull requests, starting with current missing functionality in MonoGame.

data.title: Samples should not be a submodule
data.body:
Currently the repository includes MonoGame samples as a submodule.  Unfortunately this samples repository is around 400MB total.  This means that the major component of cloning (recursively) the MonoGame repository is in the samples, which is annoying when the MonoGame repository itself is used as a submodule.

Users can't avoid this by not cloning recursively either as it's required to get the third party libraries (other than cloning repositories individually and that's horrible).  Ideally it'd be better to just remove the Samples submodule entirely and leave it to stand on it's own; or reverse the relationship and have the samples repository use MonoGame as a submodule.  Either way, removing the dependency would greatly improve the download / clone speed of MonoGame.

data.title: Window states patch.
data.body:
In XNA, graphics.IsFullScreen property usable for change device and window state but with some rules, which monogame breaks

[1]It cannot change window state directly, instead graphics.ApplyChanges must be called for applying this change to window.
[2]It can change window state after called at constructor(i e before creating GraphicsDevice), but only at constructor(nor Initilialize or LoadContent).

So, this patch fixes this behaviour.This patch also add old IsFullScreen changing behaviour to ToggleFullscreen because this method internally must use ApplyChanges. This patch also remove multiply calls of ResetWindowBounds(because it break [2] rule and absolutly not necessary). This patch enables IsFullscreen usage at constructor. Finally this patch enable fullscreen by calling IsFullscreen at constructor on WinDX platform.

What I want mark - the methods ApplyChanges,ResetWindowBounds - not change window after call, only the first time maybe, but it will not turn fullscreen up or back in normal usage in Update - means game cannot change fullscreen state at runtime. This must be fixed - but I not have much knowledge for do it(Im not familiar with opentk and d3d11 resets/swapchains). 

So, after this patch - only three visible things happens at current moment 1) after call IsFullScreen in Initialize or LoadContent - nothing will happens - instead of pre-patch situation. 2) windx projects can be runned in fullscreen mode. 3) Enables IsFullscreen usage at constructor.

data.title: Issue #1850 - Moved init of color bank to a static constructor
data.body:
This moves the initialization of the static color bank to a static constructor. The repeated new() of the prior version's color bank has a small but noticeable affect when repeatedly called from a draw or update method. This change will abate some of the mysterious overhead associated with new() on structs.

There is no change to the serialization signature of this class. Furthermore, this does not change the XNA compatibility of this class.

data.title: Refactor Android & MacOS ReImplementations of GameWindow
data.body:
In both Android and MacOS we re-impelement GameWindow instead of inheriting from it.  These are located here:
- [MonoGame/MonoGame.Framework/MacOS/GameWindow.cs](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/MacOS/GameWindow.cs)
- [MonoGame.Framework/Android/AndroidGameWindow.cs](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Android/AndroidGameWindow.cs)

We should refactor these classes to inherit directly from the GameWindow base class like we do on all the other platforms.  This not only makes maintenance and extensibility of the code easier, but makes it better for testing.
